tables.table_comment: Unified table for all measurement data: body ranges from size guides and exact garment specifications

columns.generation_expression:
CASE
    WHEN (measurement_type ~~ 'garment_%'::text) THEN 'garment'::text
    WHEN (measurement_type ~~ 'body_%'::text) THEN 'body'::text
    WHEN (measurement_type ~~ 'g_%'::text) THEN 'garment'::text
    ELSE 'body'::text
END

COALESCE(exact_value,
CASE
    WHEN ((min_value IS NOT NULL) AND (max_value IS NOT NULL)) THEN ((min_value + max_value) / (2)::numeric)
    ELSE NULL::numeric
END)

CASE
    WHEN (exact_value IS NOT NULL) THEN (exact_value)::text
    WHEN (min_value = max_value) THEN (min_value)::text
    WHEN ((min_value IS NOT NULL) AND (max_value IS NOT NULL)) THEN (((min_value)::text || '-'::text) || (max_value)::text)
    ELSE NULL::text
END

indexes.indexdef: CREATE UNIQUE INDEX measurements_pkey ON public.measurements USING btree (id)
CREATE INDEX idx_measurements_garment ON public.measurements USING btree (garment_id, size_label, measurement_category)

CREATE INDEX idx_measurements_brand ON public.measurements USING btree (brand_id, measurement_type, size_label) WHERE (garment_id IS NULL)
CREATE INDEX idx_measurements_user_measured ON public.measurements USING btree (user_id, garment_id) WHERE (source_type = 'user_measured'::text)

sample_data.raw_text:
Department: Men
Category: Tops
Fit Type: Unspecified
Unit: Inches

Alpha Size,XS,S,M,L,XL
Dual Alpha Size,XS/S,XS/S,M/L,M/L,XL/XXL
Your Chest,35"-36",37"-38",39"-40",41"-42",43"-45"

sample_data.notes: Separate from outerwear guide; excluded 'belt' column because not worth bringing in for this category or distinguishing it from waist and hips
No subcategories, applies to all tops
sample_data.raw_text:
Department: Men
Category: Tops
Fit Type: Unspecified
Unit: Inches

Alpha Size,Chest,Hip,Arm Length
XXS,33 in,32 in,30 in
XS,35 in,34 in,32 in
S,37 in,36 in,33 in
M,40 in,39 in,34 in
L,44 in,43 in,35 in
XL,47 in,46 in,36 in
XXL,50 in,49 in,37 in
XXXL,56 in,55 in,37.5 in

Reiss Men's Shirts Size Guide - Chest and Collar measurements in inches: XS(34 chest, 14.5 collar), S(36 chest, 15 collar), M(38 chest, 15.5 collar), L(40 chest, 16 collar), XL(42 chest, 16.5 collar), XXL(44 chest, 17 collar), 3XL(46 chest, 18 collar)

sample_data.raw_source_text:
SIZE GUIDE
Clive

Fit Information
• If inbetween sizes, size up
• Regular fit
• Bruce is 187 cm / 6''2 / 6''1 and is wearing a size M

Measurement Details
A) 1/2 Chest Width - Measure the Chest under the armpit straight to the other armpit. For around chest circumference, double the chest value of our chart.
B) Center Back Length - Measured at center of back from bottom of collar to the hem.
C) Sleeve Length - Measured from the shoulder seam and down the outer sleeve to the bottom of the cuff.

INCHES

SIZE	S	M	L	XL	XXL
1/2 Chest Width	19.7	20.5	21.3	22	23.2
Center Back Length	26.6	27	27.4	27.8	28.1
Sleeve Length	25.6	26	26.4	26.8	27.2

current_challenges: Dual measurement storage systems (traditional vs unified)
Potential data duplication between size_guides and measurements tables
Need for consistent measurement terminology across systems
Performance optimization for fit analysis queries
business_requirements: Store both body measurements (size guides) and garment specifications
Maintain data integrity and avoid duplication
Support both brand-level and product-specific measurements
key_questions: Should we consolidate to unified measurements table or keep dual system?
How to handle the relationship between size guides (body) and garment specs?
What's the optimal schema for fast fit analysis queries?
How to maintain backward compatibility during migration?
